awd_titl_txt: E2CDA: Type I: Probabilistic Spin Logic for Low-Energy Boolean and Non-Boolean Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Various components of hardware and software have come together to make this electronic revolution surrounding smartphones and the like possible. To further expand our capabilities, to enter a new era of even more comprehensive networking between individual users and the cloud, as well as to solve problems of a complexity level that cannot be tackled even with today's computers, there is the need to push the frontiers of data processing beyond anything that can be achieved through "conventional" electronics. One approach is to improve the hardware further. However the latter has been historically mainly focused on making devices ever smaller, thus gaining the benefit of a more compact but very power hungry electronics. The current project revolves around a novel device that uses electron spins rather than electron charges for information processing, and holds the promise to achieve the above mentioned goals at a power consumption level that is far smaller than what can be envisioned with conventional technologies. At the same time the project aims at a new level of education and dissemination through the concept that we call "atoms to systems". A new generation of engineers requires skill sets and a knowledge base that is different from what was learned previously. A high priority of the project is thus to make the models and ideas that underlie them accessible across science and engineering.

There is increasing interest in a fundamentally different form of brain-like logic based on probabilistic inference that is far more effective and energy efficient in dealing with the problems of search and recognition posed by the ever increasing amounts of "big data". Probabilistic logic is currently implemented with software algorithms that run on a deterministic computing platform. The goal is to lay the foundation for a new P(robabilistic)-computing platform using unstable multiferroics, a manmade material combination that combines distinct electrical, mechanical and magnetic properties. Unlike quantum computers, P-computers should operate robustly at room temperature, while providing some aspects of the "quantum parallelism" that facilitates the solution of hard problems. The team will work on the material, device and circuit development of this novel probabilistic computing idea. Technical work related to the characterization of novel material properties, the impact of various structural parameters and architectural aspects will all be explored in parallel by the group of experts.

por.por_cntn:
Many complex problems related to natural phenomena and modern human society are inherently probabilistic, for example, determining the traffic pattern in a city or predicting how a new virus will spread. Such problems require feeding a large amount of unstructured or random data to computers. Digital computers today cannot do that readily as they are built with deterministic—not probabilistic—hardware components to perform precise tasks. To tackle probabilistic problems like pattern recognition, highly specialized digital computers have been developed with probabilistic algorithms being implemented. However, the efficiency of these computers diminishes rapidly with the increasing complexity of the problem, with highly complex problems requiring more time and impractically large amounts of energy. Although the quantum computing paradigm promises an efficient solution to the types of problems described above, quantum computers require cryogenic temperatures, restricting the types of devices and applications for which they could be used. With the ever-increasing amount of “big data” and unprecedented growth of applications that rely on analysis of complex unstructured data, it is essential to develop a computer that is not only efficient at dealing with probabilities at large scale but also functional at ambient conditions. Realization of a probabilistic computer (p-computer) operating at room temperature will transform the current computing paradigm from advanced computation into intelligent understanding and inference.

 

The CAPSL team consists of experts in the field of materials – Jianping Wang, Ramamoorthy Ramesh – devices – Zhihong Chen, Joerg Appenzeller – modeling – Mark Lundstrom, Supriyo Datta – and architectures – Ronald DeMara, Chris Kim. This team has worked over the last four years on exploring, fabricating and characterizing the fundamental building blocks for probabilistic computing, i.e. probabilistic bits (p-bits), as well as p-circuits and suitable p-architecture. Collectively the team has made substantial progress towards the overarching goal of the center in exploring and demonstrating p-devices and p-circuits from an experimental as well as theoretical and simulation standpoint. Key research results include Jianping Wang’s group succeeding in building a 3-p-bit p-circuit employing stable magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJs) under particular magnetic field and bias conditions to create tunable fluctuations. His work clearly showed the collective response and time evolution of a p-circuit through properly designed weights between the p-bits. Ramamoorthy Ramesh’s group key discovery has been to identify the opportunity to manipulate individual spins in an Fe3+-PTO system by means of an electric field. One of Zhihong Chen’s group key research results is the experimental demonstration that random number generators made from stochastic perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) ferromagnets (FMs) pass successfully the NIST statistical test suite for small sets of bits, owing to the natural capability of fluctuating magnets to produce random signals. Another key finding of her group is that anisotropy scaling is the preferred approach to achieve fast switching and low pinning fields in p-bits. Joerg Appenzeller’s group has experimentally demonstrated successfully various types of p-bit implementations from a) hard biased PMA magnets with Oersted rings and b) spin orbit torque (SOT) controlled unstable MTJs. Another of his key results is the experimental finding that record low SOT current densities can achieve writing in two-dimensional (2D) ferromagnetic semiconductors. Supriyo Datta’s and Mark Lundstrom’s group key accomplishments has been establishing the Purdue-P website https://www.purdue.edu/p-bit/ allowing public access to a coprocessor for probabilistic spin logic (PSL). Chris Kim’s group succeeded in fabricating a 65nm Ising chip with 6 ring oscillators (ROSCs) with programmable weights. His chip demonstrated to be able to solve various Max cut problems successfully. Ron DeMara’s group key result at the circuit-level has been the development of a novel subthreshold circuit design approach to spiking neural networks providing probabilistic Hebbian plasticity with homeostasis. The developed Neural Sampling Core is capable of learning orientation selectivity, similar to the simple cells found in the visual cortex, supporting unsupervised learning.
